results.title: The Lucy show. Volume 2
results.brief_description: Lucille Ball stars as Lucy Carmichael, a widowed mother with two children living in California. She falls into a job when visiting the Vice President of the Bank, Theodore J Mooney (Gale Gordon), but is far from being a competent secretary. This tape includes four madcap tales including: “Little old lady”; at a banquet to celebrate the bank’s fiftieth anniversary Lucy dresses up as an old lady to act as chaperone to the banks 80 year old founder; Cornelius Heatherington Jr. Guest starring Dennis Day and directed by Jack Donohue. “Lucy & George Burns”; George Burns calls into the bank to collect a dividends statement. He laments the fact that he had to stop working because he ran out of comediennes, until he meets a possible leading lady; Lucy. Guest starring George Burns and directed by Maury Thompson. “Lucy gets trapped”; Lucy feigns an illness so that he she can go to a department store sale. All goes well until she is rewarded with being the 10 millionth customer and has her photograph in the paper. Directed by Jack Donohue. “Lucy & John Wayne”; Lucy delivers a contract to John Wayne, in person, despite strict instructions from Mr Mooney that she is to drop it off at reception. Guest starring John Wayne and directed by Maury Thompson. Based on the book “Life without George” by Irene Kampen.

results.title: The Lucy show. Volume 1
results.brief_description: Lucille Ball stars as Lucy Carmichael, a widowed mother with two children living in California. She falls into a job when visiting the Vice President of the Bank, Theodore J Mooney (Gale Gordon), but is far from being a competent secretary. This tape includes four madcap tales including: “Lucy & the substitute secretary”; Lucy meets the woman who is to replace her whilst she is on holidays. She begins to worry when she discovers her replacement ended up superceceding the last secretary she worked for. Lucy is up to her devilish best to prevent this from happening. “Lucy flies to London”; Lucy wins first prize in a dog food jingle contest; a trip to London. The holiday starts off on shaky ground when she finds herself seated next to Mr Mooney on the plane, guest stars include Pat Priest and James Wellman. “Lucy & the bean queen”; Mr Mooney invests in a new product, ‘Bailey’s barbequed beans’ for one of their major clients and Lucy turns out to be their biggest investor, for an unusual reason. Guest starring Ed Begley. “Lucy & the babysitter”; Lucy looks for another job to prove to Mr Mooney that she has opportunities to find something better. She finds a job babysitting through an agency, only they omit to tell her she is looking after chimpanzees and not children. Guest stars include Mary Wickes and the Marquis Chimps. Based on the book “Life without George” by Irene Kampen.

results.title: The Lucky ones: allied airmen and Buchenwald
results.brief_description: A sensitive documentary account of the experiences of several World War II veterans out of the 168 survivors of the Nazi concentration camp, Buchenwald. Upon their capture by the Gestapo in the early 1940s, these young men were sent not to a prisoner-of-war camp, as set out in international law, but transferred to the Buchenwald concentration camp, most notorious for its crematoriums and human medical experiments. Fifty years on, these men; allied airmen that were mostly recruits of 19 to 21 years of age from Canada, Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States; present their personal stories of the horror they witnessed and experienced and the certainty of imminent death or torture that met them everyday in the months they spent there. Their reflective and moving testimony follows their lives before, during and after Buchenwald and unflinchingly confronts the difficulty of life after the war carrying the indelible marks of the atrocities they survived, about which they feared no one would believe. Combining these interviews and commentaries with rare archival footage, photographs and insights from friends and family of the veterans this documentary captures a distinct part of the crimes against humanity in World War II and Holocaust history.

results.title: The Lower depths
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: Maxim Gorky’s ‘The Lower depths’ attracted two of cinema’s greatest practitioners to its pages. Just as Jean Renoir’s ‘Les Bas Fonds’ was a very French adaptation, so Kurosawa’s film is quite specifically Japanese, with Gorky’s Moscow slums transposing easily (and faithfully) to Kurosawa’s stylised Tokyo hovel. The resulting ensemble piece displays the director’s technical virtuosity and his ability to draw outstanding performances from his cast. Stars Toshiro Mifune. From the play by Maxim Gorky. Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Loves of Carmen
results.brief_description: Produced by Rita Hayworth’s production company, Beckworth, ‘The Loves of Carmen’ is a dramatised version of Carmen which is based, not on Bizet’s opera, but on the story by Prosper Merimee. This is definitely a star vehicle for Hayworth - she sizzles in the role as the beautiful and fiesty Spanish gypsy. She is joined by Glenn Ford who plays the besotted Don Jose. The film is directed by Hayworth’s favourite director, Charles Vidor, and includes some colourful dance and musical scenes, although it is essentially dramatic and not a musical. Rita Hayworth’s father assisted with some of the choreography and her uncle and brother also appear in the film.

results.title: The Lovers = Les amants
results.creator_credit: Nouvelle Edition Francaise, Irenee Leriche and Louis Malle
results.brief_description: Jeanne Moreau plays a bored, rich, provincial married woman (Jeanne) who visits Paris every weekend to escape the boredom of rural Dijon. But even Paris, and her love affair with a polo-playing playboy, cannot make her forget the ennui and tedium of her narrow life. It is only when her car breaks down and she is picked up by the cynical Bernard (Jean-Marc Borc), that Jeanne is forced to revaluate her life and the meanings she has attached to her class and position. Louis Malle’s first feature film created much controversy when released for its matter of fact treatment of adultery and its consequences. An updating of Flaubert’s “Madame Bovary”, it is the hypocrisy and selfishness of the haute-bourgeois that is condemned in “The Lovers”, rather than the sexual freedom desired by both Jeanne and Bernard. This extremely self-assured and accomplished debut is also a loving tribute to the beauty and screen magnetism of Moreau. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize at the Venice Film Festival) Cast also includes Alain Cuny as Jeanne’s sardonic entrepreneur husband.

results.title: The Love letter
results.creator_credit: NBCUniversal, Sarah Pillsbury, Midge Sanford, Kate Capshaw and Peter Ho-sun Chan
results.brief_description: The lives of residents of Loblolly by the Sea are transformed by the discovery of a passionate love letter, written to and from a nameless person. Divorcee Helen McFarquar (Kate Capshaw), first to read the letter begins a steamy romance with the much younger Johnny (Tom Everett Scott) who helps out in the bookstore where she works. The awakening of dormant feelings questions her to re-assess her relationship to George (Tom Selleck), an old friend from the past who has always been in love with her but lacks the eloquence and poetry of the letter. As the letter changes hands to Helen’s friend and co worker (Ellen DeGeneres), the local policeman, it alters their lives and those around them indelibly, and as Helen’s distant mother arrives back to Loblolly from overseas she discovers they have more in common than she realised. Cast also includes Blythe Danner and Geraldine McEwan. Based upon the novel by Cathleen Schine.
